intro: Aureolaria calycosa, commonly known as the golden catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its showy, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has hairy, upright stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands and along stream banks. Aureolaria calycosa is also known for its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
